The function returns the new function value, the old function value and the slope at the new point, in addition to the value alpha and the number of function and gradient evaluations. But this info was missing from the docstring.

author: Benjamin Trendelkamp-Schroer
title: [optimize] Bug fix of line_search_wolfe2: Optional arguments have not been passed to myfprime if the current value of the Jacobian gfk wasn't explicitly specified by the caller. This commit is to fix this bug

title: ENH: signal: enhanced scipy.signal.filtfilt * Rewrote lfilter_zi, and added a docstring that explains what it does. * Enhanced filtfilt so that it can filter a given axis in an n-dimensional array,   and also allow more flexibility in how the data is extended before filtering. * Added the module _arraytools.py, which provides the convenient functions   axis_slice and axis_reverse, and the axis extension functions odd_ext,   even_ext and const_ext. * Changes to filtfilt also fix bug #1410.

author: Warren Weckesser

author: Charles Harris
title: ENH: Add extrapolate keyword to splev to control the its behavior outside of the interval of definition. If extrapolate=1, then the current behavior is preserved, if extrapolate=0, then the spline evaluates to zero for points outside of the interval of definition. The default value is 1.

author: david.warde-farley
title: * Cleared up my understanding of :obj: vs. :func:. :func: is the right thing to be using.  * Replaced numarray with numpy wherever possible (not in code, though)  * Demarcated notes, which were previously just {} enclosed due to markup loss  * Got subsubsections working.  * Highlighting C code, linking to the Python C API (Sphinx rocks)  * Fixed up more crossreferencing stuff...  * Fixed a few typos/language errors.  * Morphology sub-heading to encompass both Binary and Greyscale, as it was before.  * currentmodule directives so that things link like they're supposed to.  * Removed "section" from the backreferences as "see section <section title>" doesn't make much sense, only makes sense if there is a number.

author: david.warde-farley
title: Yet more markup cleanup, :obj: is now used where functions are introduced and currentmodule:: has been introduced so as to enable cross-references to generated docs.

author: david.warde-farley
title: Eliminated {} around True, False, and None; fixed obvious misspellings, and added ndimage to index.rst.

author: david.warde-farley
title: Huge fixer-upper. All module functions prefixed with :func: (is this correct?). All parameters enclosed in \*param\* (seemed like the closest thing in the Sphinx documentation that I could find. Tables and sectional cross-references fixed.

title: Replaced "from numpy import *" with standard "import numpy as np". Replaced nose.run call with run_module_suite.

author: Alan McIntyre
title: Use numpy.testing.verbose to control when information not related to a test failure is displayed. Updated "if __name__ == '__main__'" boilerplate to use numpy.testing.run_module_suite instead of directly using nose.run. Removed code/functions (set_package_path,set_local_path,restore_path) that manipulates sys.path. Replaced print statements containing user warnings with warnings.warn.

Removed code/functions (set_package_path,set_local_path,restore_path) that manipulates sys.path. Replaced print statements containing user warnings with warnings.warn.

author: pierregm
title: major update ! core     : MaskedArray now really behave like ndarrays.          : got rid of (most) class default.          : now using views instead of calls to self.__class__.          : added a _smallmask attribute to prevent the automatic compression of masks.          : added a _baseclass attribute, to record the class type of the input data.          :  _data is now simply a view of self as _baseclass. extras   : corrected a pb w/ apply_along_axis. core_ini : previous version of core

author: pierregm
title: major update ! core     : MaskedArray now really behave like ndarrays.          : got rid of (most) class default.          : now using views instead of calls to self.__class__.          : added a _smallmask attribute to prevent the automatic compression of masks.          : added a _baseclass attribute, to record the class type of the input data.          :  _data is now simply a view of self as _baseclass. extras   : corrected a pb w/ apply_along_axis. core_ini : previous version of core

author: Robert Kern
title: I regenerated the extension module with SWIG 1.3.31 to incorporate a fix from the SWIG runtime. There were several instances of assigning const char* to plain-old char* that g++ 4 was creating errors for me. I also added a #include "Python.h" before the numpy headers are #included. Otherwise, the module did not compile for me on OS X with Python 2.5.

author: Robert Kern
title: I regenerated the extension module with SWIG 1.3.31 to incorporate a fix from the SWIG runtime. There were several instances of assigning const char* to plain-old char* that g++ 4 was creating errors for me. I also added a #include "Python.h" before the numpy headers are #included. Otherwise, the module did not compile for me on OS X with Python 2.5.

title: - Got least-squares optimization working - Stuck more info into my "test" function to   confirm that leastsq is doing something good - Began incorporating simplex, bfgs and ncg   (added explicit objective fxn for this to work) - discovered dot() and transpose() fxn for arrays... :)   some refactoring of matrix multiplication avoiding   conversions calls to matrix() and array()

author: Tim Hochberg
title: Check that only last axis has nonstandard strides and copy if it does. Also skip the failing (a+1)**-1 test and add a test that checks the stride behavior.

author: Tim Hochberg
title: Streamline a couple of things: first consolidate memsizes  into memsteps. Second, have all source operands respect stride. Now it's no longer necessary to copy input arguments if they are strided although it still may be a good idea if they are used more than once. In theory this could slow things down since there's more address computation, but my admittedly crude benchmarks show no noticable slowdown.

author: edschofield
title: Big sparse matrix patch:  - raise TypeError for ambiguous len(sparsematrix)  - raise IndexError for sparsematrix[i] with integer i. If allowed at all,    this should return the ith row, as for dense numpy matrices.  - more efficient .sum() and .mean() for csc and csc matrices  - more efficient .transpose() for lil matrices  - support for constructing a lil_matrix from a csr_matrix or another lil_matrix  - fix fragile slicing functionality that relied on operator.isSequenceType  - add unit tests for .mean() method and lil_matrix construction

author: edschofield
title: Big sparse matrix patch:  - raise TypeError for ambiguous len(sparsematrix)  - raise IndexError for sparsematrix[i] with integer i. If allowed at all,    this should return the ith row, as for dense numpy matrices.  - more efficient .sum() and .mean() for csc and csc matrices  - more efficient .transpose() for lil matrices  - support for constructing a lil_matrix from a csr_matrix or another lil_matrix  - fix fragile slicing functionality that relied on operator.isSequenceType  - add unit tests for .mean() method and lil_matrix construction

title: Used copy_c to reduce the number of opcodes needed to implement functions. Also cleaned up a OpFunc while redoing it to support the new copy_c approach.

author: Tim Hochberg
title: Used copy_c to reduce the number of opcodes needed to implement functions. Also cleaned up a OpFunc while redoing it to support the new copy_c approach.

author: Tim Hochberg
title: Added support for '**' and '%'. When testing these I found bugs in the compiler for division and subtraction, so I fixed those as well. Note that cont**var and const%var are implemented using copy_c, so they will be slower than the reverse operations.

author: Tim Hochberg
title: Added support for '**' and '%'. When testing these I found bugs in the compiler for division and subtraction, so I fixed those as well. Note that cont**var and const%var are implemented using copy_c, so they will be slower than the reverse operations.

title: Improve testing of two argument functions and fix the goofy bug in arctan2 that this revealed.

author: Tim Hochberg
title: Fill out the framework to work with 1 and 2-argument functions as well as 'where'. Also fixed some minor bugs and added a bunch of tests in test.py. These should really get added to test_numexpr.py, but at first glance that looks somewhat heavyweight and I don't want to look into how to use that just yet.

title: Another big sparse matrix patch:  * fixed csrmucsc() bug in sparsetools wrapper  * fixed bug in __rsub__  * enabled __radd__ unit tests  * added functionality for dense * sparse multiplication  * added more unit tests for multiplication  * simplified csc_matrix.__init__() argument parsing  * renamed conjtranspose() to getH() for compatibility with dense matrices  * more code cleanups

author: edschofield
title: Another big sparse matrix patch:  * fixed csrmucsc() bug in sparsetools wrapper  * fixed bug in __rsub__  * enabled __radd__ unit tests  * added functionality for dense * sparse multiplication  * added more unit tests for multiplication  * simplified csc_matrix.__init__() argument parsing  * renamed conjtranspose() to getH() for compatibility with dense matrices  * more code cleanups

author: edschofield
title: Patch to Travis's sparse module:  * various bug fixes  * renamed Sparse.py to sparse.py for consistency with other modules  * renamed test_Sparse.py likewise  * separated out construction of CSC and CSR matrices into two separate    functions to make testing easier and 'reduce cognitive load'  * added matrixmultiply() methods for consistency with dense matrices  * added sanity checks for dok_matrix keys and values

title: r122@Blasphemy:  kern | 2005-10-05 21:10:39 -0700  Remove attempt to load R functions if rpy is available. Just because rpy is installed doesn't necessarily mean that one wants it to be loaded. Such decisions should be left to application-level code rather than library-level code. In my opinion, at least.

author: Travis Oliphant
title: Fixed most of the tests for special functions so they pass.  Cleaned up a few of the interfaces to specfun.  All of the specfun.f interfaces need to be checked to make sure that a large enough array is passed in.  Some of the specfun routines assume that the array is at least size 2 (hard coded references to array(0) and array(1) for example).  Unless the Python interface checks to make sure that it is being called with a large enough value, the array passed to the fortran routine can be too small.  This has caused segfaults in the past and it is not entirely cleaned up.

author: Travis Oliphant
title: Changed takemask to extract.  Added inverse of extract called insert.  Extract takes 1-d array out of raveled nd array according to raveled mask.  Insert puts elements from 1-d array back into an n-d array according to mask.  It can be thought of as the inverse of extract.  It allows for operations to only be performed when necessary.

author: Pearu Peterson
title: Impl. support for ATLAS 3.2.1. One must set atlas_version_pre_3_3=1 in linalg/setup_linalg.py manually until someone figures out how to determine the ATLAS version from system_info.py. With older versions it is not easy (see http://math-atlas.sourceforge.net/faq.html#probe).   Impl. also hooks for building linalg without single precision routines to reduce the size of extension modules. By default, skip_single_routines=0 in linalg/setup_linalg.py.

author: Pearu Peterson
title: Fixed lwork check in gelss signature. It appears that it must be >=1. dgelss docs say also >=minmn+MAX(2*minmn,MAX(maxmn,nrhs) that I have now interpreted as optimal, not minimal, because the code in src/calc_lwork.f seems to be identical to dgelss.f and I still trust it... need more tests to be sure though.

author: Pearu Peterson
title: Fixed QR decomposition for complex input. The bug was in calculating   H(i) = I - tau * v * v' (see man zgeqrf) where v' must have been transpose(conjugate(v)) but was transpose(v). Using gemm to calculate H(i) and the product Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k).

author: Pearu Peterson
title: Fixed QR decomposition for complex input. The bug was in calculating   H(i) = I - tau * v * v' (see man zgeqrf) where v' must have been transpose(conjugate(v)) but was transpose(v). Using gemm to calculate H(i) and the product Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k).

title: var() was not working for multi-dimensional arrays of unequal dimensions with the reduction occuring over anything but the 0th axis. author: Eric Jones
title: major overhaul to testing framework.  module_xxx.test() now takes a 'level' argument to specify how thorough the testing should be.  Level 1 is the least thorough, and only runs rapid tests (as specified by the test writer) on the module/package.  level=10 is the most thorough testing.  Any value between 1 and 10 can be used.  I'm currently using 1, 5, and 10 for most of my tests, but others may wish to use more fine grained settings.

Level 1 is the least thorough, and only runs rapid tests (as specified by the test writer) on the module/package.  level=10 is the most thorough testing.  Any value between 1 and 10 can be used.  I'm currently using 1, 5, and 10 for most of my tests, but others may wish to use more fine grained settings.

author: prabhu
title: Added tests to check for the case when a proxied object calls a method on another proxied object inside it.  Also added an implicit test to check if a class having no __init__ can be wrapped.

author: prabhu
title: Modified the code to support cases where a proxied call would call a method of another proxied object inside it.  This happens when one gui_threaded object is embedded inside another and the one inside makes a function call which is proxied.  Cleaned up the various proxy classes.  They were all unnecessarily using references to the originally wrapped proxy class. Instead of this the proxied_callable now stores the event_catcher (the same that the proxy_base stores) and posts events to it directly.

author: prabhu
title: Fixed bug where a class having no __init__ would not be wrapped.  Now doing some name mangling for the non-proxied init2 function to prevent problems. Modified the code to support cases where a proxied call would call another proxied call inside it.  This happens when one gui_threaded object is embedded inside another and the one inside makes a function call which is proxied.  Also made modifications to make use of the new, cleaned up gui_thread_guts.py.

author: prabhu
title: Dereferencing proxy_attr instances properly.  This can be very convenient.

author: prabhu
title: Added tests that checks the return values from proxied functions.

author: prabhu
title: The proxied return types now support lists, tuples and dictionaries properly by using proxied versions of UserList and UserDict.  This makes proxying easy and natural where the proxied class returns these types.  Also made some cosmetic changes to the way gui_thread announces that it has been imported.

title: Changes to __init__ to handle lack of fft package better.

title: First set of tests for gui_thread.  Right now the tests are very trivial.

author: prabhu
title: Improved exception reporting and fixed bad bug when gui_thread is used in cases where there is no second thread.

author: prabhu
title: Improved exception reporting.  Removed a cyclic reference problem in CloseEvtHandler.

author: prabhu
title: Fixed a segfault bug in gui_thread_guts that was caused because I was using a weakref.proxy.  The exception handling code was raising an exception (by using finally) - removed that.  Also fixed bug where exception type is a string and not a class.  Creating a CloseEvtHandler for non wxWindows classes causes circular reference problems - fixed it.

author: prabhu
title: Fixed a segfault bug in gui_thread_guts that was caused because I was using a weakref.proxy.  The exception handling code was raising an exception (by using finally) - removed that.  Also fixed bug where exception type is a string and not a class.  Creating a CloseEvtHandler for non wxWindows classes causes circular reference problems - fixed it.

author: prabhu
title: Small but important fixes to improve memory management.  __del__ was being wrapped - this would mean that potentially an object might be deleted twice. Also, using weakrefs where important to prevent circular references.
